div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

SATURDAY, JUNE 3, 1905.

div.head: THE SUEZ CANAL
div.p: Last week the balance dividends to be paid by the Suez Canal Company for 1904 were announced. These showed a very considerable increment, giving rise to expectations of an early realisation of the hope, expressed by the chairman at the meeting last June, that a reduction of 50 centimes per ton in the transit dues might be possible. A reduction of this amount came into operation at the beginning of 1903; but, thanks to the growth in number and tonnage of vessels using the waterway, the decline in receipts was insignificant, only from frs. 103,720,020 to frs. 103,620,268. Economies in working enbaled the company to enlarge its dividends for 1903, frs.5 being added to the distribution on the Ordinary and redeemed shares and frs. 2 to the amount falling to the Founders. Now the total dividend which was frs. 130 net for 1903, is advanced to frs. 141 net for 1904 on the Ordinary shares of frs. 500 and the Founders' receive frs. 66.57 net, against frs. 60.50 for the preceding year. Needless, to say,

div.head: THE SUEZ CANAL [cont.]
div.p: these rates are far and away the highest ever paid by the undertaking ; indeed, the net dividend –– that is, after deduction of taxes –– exceeds the gross dividend of 1903, which was the previous best. The sum distributed in excess dividends to shareholders and founders will be nearly £2,300,000, irrespective of the Egyptian Government's 15 per cent. of the net profits (belonging since 1880 to a French company which bought it from the Government) and of the 5 per cent. interest payable on each unredeemed share. The accounts of the company have not reached us, but the annual return to Parliament, issued last week, shows that the transit receipts rose over frs. 12,000,000, to frs. 115,818,479 ––say £4,632,740.

The net tonnage passing through the Canal last year was 1,494,547 tons greater than that of 1903, and about 500,000 tons of this is atttributed to the consignments of coal to the Far East for the use of the belligerents. That, of course, accounts for only about a third of the increase, and the report of the British Government directors mentions the heavy shipments of wheat from India as explaining a great part of the remainder. The effects of the war are to be traced throughout the statistics of traffic. The interruption of Russian commercial shipping is seen in the decline from 119 in 1903 to 82 last year in the number of Russian ships, and, as the latter figure included 15 warships and transports, representing 76,763 tons out of a total of 153,848 tons, the trade in Russian bottoms is seen to have nearly disappeared. Only six Japanese ships passed through the Canal last year, against 53 in 1903, and the net tonnage felll from 220,966 to 21,463, of which 4,773 tons represented two warships and the rest four mail steamers, leaving not a solitary Japanese merchant vessel in the list. The percentage of British traffic continues to grow, and we show the figures for the next five years :––

Germany is still an indifferent second, her net tonnage advancing from last year from 1,773,265 to 1,969,561, against the British growth from 7,403,533 tons to 8,833,929 tons. The German increase in number of ships and their aggregate burthen did not improve her proportion, which fell from 13.1 per cent. of ships in 1903 to 12.8 per cent., and from 14.9 per cent. of net tonnage to 14.7 per cent. If merchant vessels alone are to be reckoned, the British proportion of tonnage rises to 76 per cent. and the German falls to 10.5 per cent., a proportion exceeding that of France, Holland, Norway, Austria-Hungary, and Italy combined. The average net tonnage of vessels using the Canal last year was 3,163, against 1,787 tons twenty years ago and 657 tons in the first year of the canal's existence. In that year (1869) the Canal earned frs. 54,5460 on 10 vessels ; the receipts got over frs. 5,000,000 in 1870, over frs 50,000,000 in 1881, and over frs. 100,000,000 in 1901, though within the last period mentioned the dues fell from frs.11.50 to frs.9 per ton.

div.head: THE NAVAL BATTLE. THE MODERN NELSON. RUSSIAN EXPLOITS.
div.p: Tokio, June 2.
On the opening of the battle Admiral Togo signalled —"The destiny of our Empire depends on this battle, and the country hopes that you will all do your utmost." (Reuter.)
ST. PETERSBURG, June 2.

The captain of the “Izumrud” reports 10 casualties. After escaping from the disaster he made the Bay of Vladimir instead of Vladivostok on account of insufficiency of coal. He there ran on a reef in the darkness, landed the crew, and blew up the ship.

The captain of the torpedo-boat "Bravi," which took 175 men rescued from the “Oslyabia” to Vladivostok, reports 14 casualties. He burned all the ship's woodwork on account of his coal running out. (Reuter.
Tokio, June 2.
The sinking of the Russian cruiser “Zhentebug" is confirmed. (Reuter.)

div.head: A JAPANESE INVASION. POPULARLY DISCUSSED IN RUSSIA.
div.p: St. PETERSBURG, June 2.
The possibility of a Japanese bombardment and invasion of the Baltic sea ports is popularly discussed in Russia. (Reuter.)

div.head: ANGLO-JAPANESE AGREEMENT. SPEECH BY LORD LANDSDOWNE.
div.p: LONDON, June 2.

At a Conservative dinner at the Holborn Restaurant, Lord Landsdowne, referring to the hope expressed by Sir Ed. Grey that the Anglo-Japanese Agreement would be maintained, said that at no time on either side had there been any question whatever of withdrawal from the alliance. It is our opinion that, when the time comes when we must consider the renewal of the agreement, the only practical question will be whether we should not seek some means of strengthening and consolidating it. The alliance has been a potent instrument lor maintaining peace, and if it be possible so to modify it that it would prevent the spread of a conflagration when it has begun, but prevent the conflagration from breaking out, all true lovers of peace would recommend such modifications ,

There has never been a moment when our relations with France were upon a firmer base, and if the inner history of the anxious mouths lately passed be ever written, it will show that our understanding with France has greatly mitigated the friction and trouble inevitable when a great war is still in progress. Our alliance with Japan and our agreement with France are alike with no selfish or aggressive purpose in view. Our sole object has been to secure peace and restrict the evils of war. (R.)

div.head: PEACE OVERTURES
div.p: PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S OFFER OF SERVICES.
WASHINGTON, June 3.

Count Cassini called on President Roosevelt yesterday. The President expressed the earnest hope,as a friend of Russia, that she would seek to conclude peace with Japan in response to the wish of the entire civilised world. The prolongation of the war would mean increased Japanese demands. He pointed out that Russia could hardly hope to win, and that influenced solely by motives of humanity he offered his services as a mediator or an intermediary in any way acceptable to Russia. Count Cassini replied that he was without instructions, but that be personally believed that Russia would continue the war, because the moment is not advantageous for the discussion of peace Russia has not lost any of her own territory and nothing in the present situation necessitates suing for peace. He promised, however, to communicate President Roosevelt's view and offer to the Tsar. (Reuter.)
LONDON, June 3.

The "Standard" learns from Washington that the American Ambassador at St Peters burg has been instructed to communicate Pre-dent Roosevelt’s conception of the position of Japan, namely that an indirect proposition for peace would be acceptable, and the slightest opening in that direction would be utilised.
The "Daily Chronicle" reports that President Roosevelt has communicated to Count Cassini information received from the Japanese Minister relative to Japan's footings regarding the situation. (Reuter.

div.head: PARIS BOMB OUTRAGE. SUPPOSED AUTHOR ARRESTED.
div.p: Paris, June 2.

The supposed author of the attempt on King Alfonso's life is Ferras, a Spaniard. The police have arrested another Spaniard, Vallina who stated that he had been preparing the attempt for a month. ( Havas. )

div.head: BOMB OUTRAGE AT BARCELONA
div.p: BARCELONA, June 2.
A bomb exploded at the military governor 's palace, causing serious damage. Ten arrests have been made.

div.head: WHITBY ELECTION
div.p: London, June 2.
Mr. Buxton, Liberal, has been elected by 4,547 votes against Major Beckett, Unionist, (4,102). (Reuter.)

div.head: GOVERNOR OF GIBRALTAR RESIGNS.
div.p: LONDON, June 2.
The War Office announces that Lieut. General Sir M. Nicholson has been permitted, for private reasons, to resign the appointment of Governor of Gibraltar. (Reuter.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: QUARANTINE against arrivals from Leith in Egyptian ports has been removed.
The Plague—Yesterday’s bulletin records two cases (one fatal) and a death in hospital at Daman hour.
Assiout Moudirieh.—In the Budget for 1906 a sum of LE. 4,000 is to be allotted for completing the Moudirieh building at Assiout.
Egyptian Estates, Ltd.—This company has now received notice from the President of the Stock Brokers' Association of Alexandria that an official quotation has been granted for the company’s shares.

As Asylum Case.—The Greek Consulate-General at Cairo is enquiring into the alleged sequestration of Mr. J. Valenzda in Abbassieh Lunatic Asylum. He is a Greek notable of Beni Souef and has a fortune of £ 10,000.

THE Ghirgeh.Scandal.—The Assiout Court of 1st Instance will sit to morrow to try the accused officials, Hassan Bey Wassif, Moudir of Ghirgeh and the Judge of the Tahta Mehkemeh Sharieh for the fraud which they are accussed of having committed in the Rifai affair.

Coal Imports.—From Jan. 1 to June 1 the imports of coal into Egypt amounted to 361,183 tons, of which Wales sent 210,966 tons, Newcastle 68,434, Scotland 45,329, Yorkshire 21,221, and other districts 15,243 tons. During the corresponding period of 1904 the imports were 416,405 tons.

Egyptology at Liverpool.—The well known Egyptologist, Mr. John Garstang, reader in Egyptian Archaeology at the University of Liverpool, will be unable to deliver a full course of lectures during the summer term, 1905. A public lecture will be delivered this month on his return from Egypt.

Sad Death.—A Greek boy of ten years met his death under painful circumstances yesterday. He was playing on the staircase of bis parents' house with a pair of scissors in his hand, when he stumbled and fell, the scissors entering his left ear and passing almost right through his head. He was at once removed to hospital, but expired on reaching it.

The Onion Crop. - The total shipments of onions from Alexandria up to date amount to 2,060,000 bags. This is the biggest crop ever known. Last year s shipments up to date were only 1,445,000 bags. The quantity of onions tail in the country is still large, and as there is no further demand for export, Egypt will use the existing stock for its own consumption, and will have no need of taking any of the Syrian crops, which come in through the autumn and winter. '

All Saints', Cauro.—Dean and Mrs. Butcher are leaving Egypt tor the summer on the 6th inst. Mrs. Butcher will not be “at home" to-day nor on any subsequent Saturday till further notice. The Rev. J. T. Burns will be staying at Church House from Saturday till Monday, every week. Notices for him, and letters, will be sent down to the Villa Eden in Boulac on other days in the week, They should however reach Church House before 11 a.m. The Shoubra service will be discontinued until further notice.

Alhambra Theatre.--- Il Duchino (Le Petit Duc) was produced last night before a large and fashionable audience, the performance meeting with great success. Signa. Im bimbo was a sprightly and vivacious Duca, and was well supported by Signa. Sevres as the Du chessa, while Sig. Berardi as the tutor was excruciatingly tunny. The piece will be repeated to-night. To-morrow, II Venditore di Uccelli will be given as a matinee, and in the evening a gala performance of Ali Baba will be given under the patronage of Baron Acton, Italian Consul General, on the occasion of the Festa dello Statuto.

Suez Canal.--Sir. Howard Vincent has given notice to ask the Chancellor of the Ex chequer if his attention has been called to the declaration on May 22, of a dividend for the past year by the Suez Canal Company, which will give the British Government a dividend tor the past year of nearly 28 per cent., free of taxes, on the investment of £4,000,000 in 1875; and, if so, whether he will consider the desirability of refunding to British tonnage passing through the canal last year some proportion, say, 5 or 10 per cent, of the dividend, having regard to the charges it had to meet to earn such an income for the company

POLICEMAN Shoots AN ITALIAN—A most unfortunate and serIous affray took place yesterday evening in Sisters-street, Alexandria, in which a member of the Alexandria City Police (an Italian) was seriously implicated While in plain clothes he had a discussion with a compatriot in a drinking place in the street The subject of the discussion is believed to have been a woman, and the two Italians grew more and more excited until from words they came to blows. The policeman drew a loaded revolver and held it at his compatriot in a menacing manner. The latter sprang at him and in a fierce struggle endeavoured to disarm his opponent But the policeman succeeded in holding on to the weapon, and, getting his arms free, he emptied the contents of two of the chambers into the man’s body, who fell writhing to the floor. The injured man was at once conveyed to the European Hospital, and it is not expected that the two wounds he sustained will be mortal. According to the latest accounts he is progressing as satisfactorily as can be expected under the circumstances. The policeman was arrested and disarmed, and subsequently handed over by the authorities of the Alexandria City Police to the Italian Consulate. It is needless to state that he will be expelled from the police force.

div.head: STRANGE CASES IN CAIRO. ALLEGED VACCINATION SCANDAL.
div.p: Considerable sensation has occurred in Cairo owing to the report that two deaths have taken place in the Capital within the last few days as the result of vaccination.

The German Consulate has opened an enquiry into the circumstances attending the death of Mr. Heinrich Klein, a young German who died at one of the Cairo Hospitals on Thursday evening after an illness of some days, which is alleged to have been occasioned by some vaccine given him by a local medical man.
A Cairo contemporary remarked yesterday —

Une certaine emotion regne en villa a la suite de deux deces survenus a la suite de vaccination. On dit—et nous reproduisons ces bruits sous toutes reserves—que les instruments qui out servi a l'operation n’auraient pas ete suffisamment sterilises. Sur trois cas de vaccination, deux ont eu une issue fatale.

It is sincerely to be hoped that a satisfactory explanation of these cases will be discovered, as if it is found that the deaths ensued owing to the reason given above, a serious set back might be given to the progress of vaccination in Egypt. During last year 408,981 successful vaccinations were performed, as compared with 408,856 in 1903. it would be a great pity if this steady progress in vaccinating were checked owing to the alarm arising from the fatality in Cairo. The importance of vaccination in Egypt is very great, and we may mention that, out of 185 cases of small-pox which were reported in Cairo last year, one-half occurred amongst the European population, more especially amongst the Greeks. This large number of cases amongst Europeans appears to be due to want of vaccination on their part. Many of the Greek patients were treated at the hospital for infectious diseases, and it is reported that those who contracted the disease severely and died had never been vaccinated.

The vaccine produced at the Cairo Vaccine Institute has up to now given very satisfactory results. There were no less than 4,155 cases of small-pox, of which 854 terminated fatally, in Egypt last year.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Regent has received a telegram inform ing him that H.H. the Khedive left Constantinople for Vienna yesterday afternoon.

On his voyage to Constantinople the Khedive called at Rhodes on the 26th May and embarked on board the S.S. "Amphitrite" his eldest daughter, who has been staying on that island for some time past owing to the delicate state of her health.
This Princess will probably return with her mother from Constantinople to Alexandria in the autumn.

div.head: THE POLICE SCHOOL
div.p: A sum of L.E. 60,000 will be allowed for in the 1906 Budget for the construction at Abbassieh of a new police school. The present site of the school is at Boulac. The institution holds an important place, for here cadet officers and non-commissioned officers an trained. An extra grant for this school, amounting to L.E.

1,394, was made in the Estimates for the current year, thus enabling 40 cadet officers and 160 oadet non-commissioned officers to be trained. This is six officers and 120 non-commissioned officers more than in 1904. A new building is much required. Plans and estimates are being prepared, but in view of the very targe demands for public buildings of all sorts, which are being pressed on the Government from every quarter, work on the new school cannot be begun tor some months yet.

div.head: BOULAC CRICKET TEAM.
div.p: Through the individual efforts of players Boulac have up to date been able to ward off defeat. The chief features during last month’s cricket were the excellent batting performances of the Rev. J. T. Burns, Mr. W. B Davies, J D. Streeter, the fine bowling displays by Messrs. W. Greenbalgh, R. Appleby, J. T. Burns, and J D. Streeter. Boulac may not be what one would call first-class in England, but they are precious near it, in the fielding department.

div.head: NEW MUSIC HALL FOR ALEXANDRIA
div.p: Alexandria is at last within measurable distance of possessing a music ball which will be worthy of the city. We say this in no disparagement of the establishment, known as the Alhambra, which has been conducted with remarkable success by Mr. Conegliano for some years past Mr. Conegliano, however, has hitherto laboured under a great disadvantage in that his tenure of the theatre site has been a most uncertain one. Now, as we announced yesterday, the proprietor of the Alhambra has signed a ten years’ lease with the owner of the ground, Mr. G. B. Alderson, and his tenure is secure et least for that period.

The result of this agreement is that a new music-ball is to be built on the plot of ground contiguous to the present Alhambra, on the south side, which is now used as a garden. The theatre will be larger than the existing one, with attractive boxes and the additional feature of a gallery. It will be entirely constructed of iron, and will comprise every modern contrivance against the chances of an outbreak of fire. The plans have been prepared and are to be sent in a few days to England, where the theatre is to be built and sent out here to be put together.

div.head: HUTCHINSON NURSING HOME
div.p: Our Cairo Correspondent writes"--- Cairenes, unlike Alexandrians, cannot complain of a want of Nursing Homes, for there are now three such institutions in Cairo, the latest being the Hutchinson Nursing Home, which was opened about a fortnight ago and which I have had an opportunity of visiting. This horne is well adapted to both surgical and medical cases, the rooms on the second floor being set apart for the former cases and those on toe first floor for the latter. The tourist, too, who has come to Egypt for change and rest, and who is not actually ill, but feels himself unable to stand the bustle and racket of hotel life, will find himself well-cared for here, and he will also have the services of the resident medical officer at his disposal, should he require them. Patients, however, may be attended by their own doctors.

A visit to this Home shows the great care with which every detail in the planning and furnishing of it has been thought out, and not a single possible want of a patient has been left unsupplied. Every room is fitted with the latest electrical conveniences, in the way of stoves, lights, and fans, is furnished in the most luxurious manner, and has the advantage of being differently arranged and furnished to any of its companions, so that every taste is suited. Separate parte of the house are also apportioned to the nurses, to the Goanese servants, and to the Arabs. There are in all twelve single rooms set apart for patients, and in addition to these they have both an exceedingly comfortable and well-arranged diningroom and a lounge which will compare favorably with any first-class hotel drawing room.

div.head: KARIANS IN EGYPT
div.p: Prof. Sayce has completed a study of some Lydian and Karian inscriptions discovered in Egypt, and lately published in a more or less revised form. Two new characters --one identical with the Cypriote to and the other with the apparent value of a — are the chief features of these, and it should be noted that most of them are to be need boustrophedon. The paper will shortly be published in the Proceedings of the Society of which Prof. Sayce is the President, and, with his former communications on the subject, make up all the Karian and Lydian texts yet discovered. Most of them are of but a few lines each, and the Lydian and Karian alphabets seem to be the greatest acquisitions that they have yet yielded. It is a pity that those interested in the subject do not turn their attention to the Greco-Egyptian Magic Papyri, among the so-called "gibberish” incantations of which are several words ending ia -anda, which may not improbably turn out to be Karian. The settlement of many Karian mercenaries in the Fayoum and elsewhere must certainly have left traces in the literature of their adopted country, could we only hit upon them.

div.head: NOTES FROM CYPRUS
div.p: TRADE COMBINATION.
( From our correspondent. )
Nicosia, May 36.

The idea of combining together for trade purpose* cannot yet be said to have made much headway among the commercial community of Cyprus. The people of Larnaca and Limassol are now, however, to have an opportunity of becoming familiarised with this method of doing business, as a steamship company has lately been formed at both places, mainly for cargo trade with Egypt, while an important brick and tile factory has just commenced operations at Limassol as a societe anonyme.

It is to be hoped that the two steamship companies will not work on rival lines, but that they will see the wisdom of uniting together and so acquire sufficient power to do a useful and profitable carrying trade with our nearest markets.

If the brick and tile factory succeeds in producing good-building material at a moderate price it should have a successful future. There is an evident tendency in this island to use roofing tiles in place of the mud roofs, and it is regarded rather as a mark of superiority for a villager to roof his building. Several mud cottages were washed away in the Limassol district during the last winter season, and this should stimulate the taste for bricks, which will not be so easily affected by wet weather.

div.head: PREVALENCE OF SCALE DISEASE.
div.p: There are complaints of scale disease among the carob and fruit trees in various parts of the island. On the other hand it is reported that the unusually heavy winter rains have washed the scale from many orange and lemon trees which had been affected, and that a larger crop of fruit yielding better prices has resulted.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL
div.p: The Legislative Council, which reassembled only on the 17th inst., brought the present session to an end on the 22nd inst.

div.head: EMPIRE DAY
div.p: Wednesday, 24th inst., being "Empire Day," and the birthday of the late Queen Victoria, was kept here as an official holiday.

div.head: FOOD AND DRUGS ACT
div.p: A Food and Drugs Act has been an important piece of local legislation during the past session.

div.head: ESTABLISHMENT OF BONDED WAREHOUSE
div.p: The “Cyprus Gazette" of 19th inst. publishes an Order by the High Commissioner, approving of a general bonded warehouse being established in the Customs stores at Larnaca in which goods destined for local consumption or for re-exportation may be deposited.

div.head: THE SOAP INDUSTRY
div.p: There is also gazetted an Order in Council reducing the import duty leviable on vegetable oils used in the manufacture of soap from the £2 per 100 okes heretofore charged ; provided that such oils are rendered unfit tor alimentary purposes at the expense of the importer and under the supervision of the Customs. This reduction of duty should give a considerable impetus to the local soap industry. Some years ago there were seven or eight soap factories in the island, the import duty on oils then being at the rate now fixed by the new order. The duty, however, was raised to £2 per 100 okes in order to prevent the importation of cotton seed oil for adulteration with the native olive oil, and as a consequence this industry was crippled and there exists to-day only one small soap factory. It is generally felt that the reduction in the duty is a wire measure.

div.head: EXODUS OF OFFICIALS
div.p: There will be a great exodus daring the next few weeks of officials going on leave. Among those going by to-day’s mail is Mrs. Collet, wife of Mr. Wilfred Collet, C.M.G., Commissioner of Nicosia, who is shortly proceeding to England prior to taking up the duties of his new appointment as Colonial Secretary, British Honduras.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Sirdar, H. E. Sir F. R. Wingate Pasha, arrived at Cairo this morning by the 7.20 train from Luxor. He was accompanied by Miralai Matchett Bey, Financial Secretary Said Bey Chokar, and several English and Egyptian officers. He will leave for Europe on the 10th inst.
Lieutenants C.K. Magill and G. R. V. Steward, of the 2nd Battalion R. Inniskilling Fusiliers, have been granted leave of absence, the former for three months and the latter for four months.
Sir Rudolph Slatin Pasha leaves Alexandria this afternoon for Trieste en route for Vienna, where he will await the arrival of the Sirdar and they will go to England together.

A large number of persons are leaving Egypt on Tuesday by the P. and O. S.S. "Arabia." Among the Alexandria departures are Mr. Mr. and Mrs. Haselden, Mr. B. S. Seed end family, and Miss Evans, Mrs. W. T. Smith and Miss Lamb. Altogether about 30 bookings from Alexandria have been taken by the steamer.

div.head: DE VERE TRUST
div.p: The usual half-yearly meeting of the above Trust was held by kind permission of Idris Bey Ragheb. M W. G. M of Egypt, in the committee room of the Grand Lodge on Tuesday evening last, 30th May. There were present: Dr. W. C. Mackenzie, Messrs. P. Plunkett, and F. A. Beale, president. The minutes of the last half-yearly and extraordinary meet-ing were read, passed, and confirmed. Mr. G. Scott-Dalgleish wrote regretting his inability to he present owing to another meeting. The President next produced the balance-sheet for the half-year ending May, which, after being audited, was unanimously accepted The balance-sheet shows a net total of credit amounting to L.E. 387.621, a considerable increase over the balance of the last half-year. It was notified that the monies had been invested in accordance with the wishes of the trustees and that the bonds had been deposited with the Trust bankers.

A letter was read from Mr. Jas. Edgell, J. P. (the trustee in England) who was watching the local trustee's interests over Dora and Reggie De Vere. A good amount was given of the program they were making with their stadias, etc. It was proposed that a hearty vote of thanks be accorded to Mr. Edgell for his greet kindness to three orphan children ; he had them at his home on every occasion, and be was using every endeavour to gain admission into the Duke of York's Royal Military School for Reggie, the necessary certificates being asked for from the trustees. A cordial vote of thanks was also expressed to the Permanent Committee of the National Grand Lodge of Egypt, for their kindness in again voting the sum of L.E. 20 from the Benevolent Fund for the year 1904.

The President intimated that he had now been three years president of the Trust and in thanking the trustees for their help and sup port, tendered his resignation. Dr. W. C. Mackenzie proposed re-election, strongly urged by Mr. Plunkett. The President, whilst acknowledging

lodging the honor and confidence of the vote, thought that as the work was now all in a satisfactory and smooth condition, some other member of the Trust should have a turn as president. Dr. Mackenzie still strongly urged Mr. Beale to accept the position for a farther period, which was finally agreed to by him. At the same time the trustees wished it to be placed on record that they fully appreciated the fact that it was owing to his untiring efforts that the funds were in such a satisfactory conuition.
A copy of the balance-sheet follows for the information of those who so generously came forward in the cause of charity :—

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit---within certain necessary limits--free discussion.
PIGEON SHOOTING.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir.–– I must protest against the arguments of "Pigeon" in to-day's issue. I daresay that when bull-baiting was abolished as pastimes as cruel were cited in justification, as "Pigeon" now cites fox-hunting. It is not because we are not in England that we should abstain from using our influence to prevent cruelty, though unfortunately this argumentt seems to prevail a great deal. The S.P.C.A. and the authorities do all they can to improve matters, but the average European, Britisher included, however revolted he may be by the particular case before him is generally too indifferent to take the small amount of trouble necessary to ensure at any rate the punishment of one offender, and the consequent gradual improvement of the lot of dumb creatures generally in Egypt. We cannot get things right all at once ; let us do all we can to arrive at this by degrees, Yours truly, Clay-Pigeon.
Cairo, May 31.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Dear Sir, –– "Pigeon," in your yesterday's issue, urges the introduction of pigeon shooting within the premises of the Alexandria Sporting Club on the plea that we are not in England and therefore the non-English members of the club might do as they like. I think this is the very reason why the butchery of harmless birds should be tabooed from a cosmopolitan club. To introduce a game or pastime which is distasteful to some of the members and has the expressed disapprobation of their Queen, is, to say the least, in very bad taste. However, I suppose British memberes have a right to kick against a general club, started since the British flag first floated over Alexandria, being turned into a slaughter ground. ––Yours truly,
"British Pigeon."
Cairo, June 1.
PUMPS IN EGYPT
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir, –– My attention has just been called to a letter in your issue of May 8, on "Pumps in Egypt," signed by F. Allen, director of Messrs. Allen, Alderson & Co. The only possible for the explanation in this letter of the names of J. and H. Gwynne and Gwynne & Co., is to lead your readers to assume that Messrs. Allen, Alderson & Co. had given up at their own desire the agencies of these two firms, now combined and known as Gwynnnes, Limited. This, however, was very far from being the case. The firm of Allen Alderson was originally started in 1868 by Mr. Stafford S. Allen as S.S. Allen & Co., with J. and H. Gwynne and Ransome, Sims, and Heads' agencies. After the death of Mr. S.S. Allen (his firm at that time holding the agency for centrifugal pumps for Egypt of J. and H. Gwynne) I was of the opinion that the terms of the agreement were not being carried out in their entirety by the new firm of A. A. & Co. I therefore in 1872 paid a visit to Egypt and my investigations fully confirmed what I anticipated, and I then terminated the agreement. I need not refer further to this subjet, or the subsequent reason for Messrs. Gwynne & Co. discontinuing their agency. I wish to call your attention, however, to one or two misleading statements in Mr. Allen's letter.

(1) As to the general efficiency of centrifugal pumps: –– Mr. Allen says, "We are prepared to guarantee in all sizes about 80% mechanical efficiency with these pumps." Such a statement from one who professes to be intimate with the subject does the cause of centrifugal pumps much harm, as it should be well-known that in certain sizes and lifts such results cannot be attained. I scarcely think that Mr. Allen's principals, Messrs. Ruston Proctor & Co., will be gratified with Mr. Allen's exposure of their methods in designing, namely, that they sent to the Continent, purchased centrifugal pumps, tested them, examined them, took them to pieces, copied them, and re-introduced them under some other name.

(2) Mr. Allen states, –– "The efficiency of some of these pumps is very good and much in advance of what British makers are as a rule disposed to guarantee." I entirely repudiate this statement and can prove that large numbers of my company's pumps have been at work for many years and have, and are still giving out, over 80% efficiency, that the best pumps made on the Continent and elsewhere are with some slight modifications copies of the pumps made and introduced from time to time by Gwynnes, that in other cases they have been re-patented or re-introduced under other names (as Mr. Allen's principals appear to be doing in the case of their new pump), as can be seen from a perusal of John Gwynne's Centrifugal Pump Patent No. 13,577 of 1851, with the thirty-five (35) claims set out therein.

I challenge Mr. Allen to prove that any of the pumping installations made by either his principals or by Continental engineers have given better results on the same lifts and under similar conditions, to those manufactured by my company, and I have no doubt that I can arrange for as many sets and sizes as Mr. Allen can name to be tested by independent experts with the machinery that he is prepared to champion.

It may be that Continental engineers have reduced the consumption of steam in ther engines (much increasing the first cost) by the introduction of elaborate valve gear, superheated steam, &c., but it has yet to be shown whether the introduction of these expensive engines will prove in the long run a real economy in Egypt, where the atmosphere is charged with large quantities of sand and grit. ––I am, etc.,
John Gwynne.
81 Cannon St., London, May 26.

div.head: Le commerce des armes en Egypte
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur
de l'"Egyptian Gazette."

Jusqui'ici l'Egypte etait affranchie de ces innombrables decrets dont on commerce a etre excede en Europe. Cela ne contribuait pas peu a faire de ce beau pays une contres privilegiee sous le rapport de la liberte individuelle, dont la population d'ailleurs tant europeenne qu'indigene ne songeait pas a abuser.

Malheureusement, la vallee du Nil n'a rieu perdu pour attendre et ces derniers temps ont ete pour elle exceptionnellement feconds en "arretes" de toutes sortes, qui doivent theoriquement etre consideres comme excellents, mais qui n'en sont pas moins des entraves a la liberte dont je viens de parler.

Il semble par la promulgation du reglement regissant le commerce des armes qu'on veuille inaugurer en Egypte l'ere des lois vexatoires, qui etaient jusqui'ici une specialite de l'empire moscovite. Ce reglement est presque la reproduction des lois en vigueur au Congo, au Cameroun, au Niger, au Senegal, dans l'Ouganda et au Soudan, pays qui sont encore a l'etat sauvage et qui ne sauraient raisonnablement etre compares au notre.

Il suffit pour constater le caractere tyrannique de la loi, de lire les articles qui soummettent les armuriers aux visites domiciliaires de la police a tout instant du jour ou de la nuit, et qui les obligent de tenir des registres ou ils devront relater "toutes les ventes effectuees avec indication de l'espec d'armes vendues, du numero d'inscription, des noms, prenoms, domicile, profession de l'acheteur, le prix d'achat, la provenance et le prix de ente de l'article."

On se fait deja une idee de ce que sera un etablissement mis a la discretion des moindres caprices des agents de la police locale. Quant aux registres, comment l'armurier pourra-t-il, dans un pays si mefiant, faire decliner le nom veritable du client pour le consigner dans un registre destine a la police. Faudra-t-il l'obliger de se pourvoir d'un extrait d'etat civil et de venir en compagnie de deux temoins? C'est la, on le voit, une loi qui ne pourra jamais passer dans la pratique. Quant aux prix d'achat et de vente, on ne comprend guere l'interet que peut avoir le Gouvernement a les savoir, alors que les armes sont estimees a la Douane, pour la perception des droite.
Toutes ces mesures, sussi inutiles qu'arbitraires, ne serviront en somme qu'a causer des ennuis aux armuriers et de l'embarras a la police.

Le Gouvernment a declare, pour s'excuser, s'inquieter du grand nombre de fusils qui entrent annuellement en Egypte. Cette augmentation est pourtant justifee par l'enorme extension de la culture de terres, qui exige une grande distribution des fusils aux gardiens, par la qualite inferieure des fusils qui sont hors d'usage au bout de quelques mois et enfin par la chasse qui est toujours plus en vogue dans ce pays au fur et a mesure que sa prosperite augmente.

Il n'y a donc pas lieu de redouter une telle progression dans le debit des armes ; ce debit rentre dans les causes normales de la richesse du pays. D'ailleurs la loi de Novembre dernier a eu pour effet de restreindre sensiblement la vente des fusils.
Armiger.
Alexandrie, le 2 juin 1904.

div.head: WORLD'S OLDEST INHABITANT.
div.p: The world's oldest inhabitant is said to be a giant tortoise, who spends his time near a stove in a naturalist's place at St. Louis. Toto is his name, and we are told he was grown when Columbus sailed. He was middle-aged and of family when the Puritans landed on Plymouth Rock. When Jamestown was founded he had a city of his own. Age had begun to deaden his faculties when Napoleon swept Europe. Toto may live to see Maculay's New Zealander explore the ruins of London.

A mark was put on his shell early in the seventeenth century. He has carried the naked children of the Seychelles Islands ; he has carried the midshipmen of the forgotten wooden frigates of Nelson's days. Perhaps Drake's hardy mariners wrote him. The children of the World's Fair were his last riders. For centuries Toto has lived and wooed. Tigers have broken their talons his sharded back. Elephants have vainly tried to crush him. Balls have glanced harmlessly from his shell. To-day he huddles by the fire, the one indestructible, undying animal of Earth. Like the Indian and Yogi, he dozes and dreams, and only asks warmth and a bite to eat.

The deep indentations on Toto's shell determine his age. It is certain that he was full grown when Captain Cook sailed in the Pacific and gave his name to fame. Toto survived, and will survive, perhaps when all the merry tots who have ridden him die grey-haired men and women.

div.head: SUPERSTITION OF THE WOMAN-SPECULATOR
div.p: A sneaking belief in "luck" or "ill-luck" is innate in most people, but it is said that for blind downright faith in good or bad omens, the woman who dabbles in stocks or shares is hard to outdo.

Many a woman speculator never stirs without her "mascot," and should she inadvertently omit to have it with her when about to embark on some important business, she will let the most promising opportunities pass rather than risk a venture unaided by her pet fetish.

As she snatches a hasty breakfast in the intervals of studying the money columns of the daily paper, she seeks to read the future in the grounds of her coffee cup, and settles her daily business in advance by the aid of this unfailing medium.

If the number of the car in which she drives into town is an unlucky one, or should she catch sight of a black cat, a person with a squint, or a one-legged man, she knows to a certainty that misfortune is in store for her.

Some women select the quaintest and most original talismans to ward off the "evil eye." One pins her faith to a weird and fanciful Maori charm with perhaps some sombre past history she knows not of, another to a tiny coralled hand with uplifted dagger of Italian manufacture, or perhaps a bronze lizard, a crystal pig, or a rabbit's foot. Others, again, see special virtue in a lucky sixpence or in some bent or crooked coin, to whose aid they may attribute all the lucky deals which have been carried out with success.
Seeing the moon through glass is regarded by the woman-speculator as an omen of disaster should she embark on any venture during the month.

div.head: MALARIA IN ITALY
div.p: An interesting report has been issued at Rome on the work accomplished by the Red Cross Society in the Roman Campagna in combating the malaria. The society has seven stations in the Campagna, and its methods are very systematic. The population of the Agro Romano consists of two classes –– those who live there all the year round and those who only come down to the plain from the mountains for a certain season of the year. A further classification divides the permanent and temporary population of this vast district into those who are considered immune from malaria and those who are liable to it. These latter receive from the society five to six tabloids of quinine a day for a week, and then one to two tabloids daily according to their age; the former one to two tabloids a day throughout the bad season without the heavy preliminary doses applied in the case of malarial subjects. The results of this treatment have been to diminish the amount of malaria in the Campagna very considerably, so that last year out of 12,061 persons who took the prescribed doses of quinine only 800 caught malarial fever, that is to say, between 6 and 7 per cent. Such is the result of the society's fifth year of work.

In addition to quinine most houses most houses, all railway stations, octroi offices, and public buildings in the neighborhood of Rome have their windows covered with close wire netting, and the octroi officials wear wire masks towards sundown, which give them the appearance of bandits in disguise.

div.head: UNDER THE MOSQUITO NET.
div.p: It is exceedingly gratifying to find that the proposal of the A.S.C. to introduce pigeon shooting on the club ground, is meeting with strenuous opposition. It will be simply disgraceful if the committee persist in their intention, and if the members of the club permit them to carry out such a retrograde step.

Surely the time has passed even in Egypt for fresh opportunities to be created for the practice of cruelty such as that involved in the shooting of innocent birds for gambling purposes, disguised under the name of sport. Even the few who defend the practice cannot deny its cruelty, and have nothing to urge in its favor, merely contenting themselves with comparing it with other undoubtedly cruel pastimes.

How on earth can cruelties practised in England or on the continent condone wrong done in Egypt? This, too, is not a question of the abolition of pigeon shooting at the Velodrome, but one of the institution at the A.S.C., a club mainly, though by no means entirely, supported by British residents.

And what steps are its influential patrons taking to protest against the course adopted by the club committee? Many have left Egypt for the summer vacation, but the names of many who have not yet gone will readily be called to mind, and it will be shameful if they permit this to take place without a word of remonstrance against the inquity of the thing.

People seem somehow to be tongue-tied in Egypt, and to have so many diverse interests to study that they are afraid to open their mouths. Letters to the paper we get, but they are mostly written under noms-de-plume, and as a consequence do not carry anything like the weight they would if the writers signed their names. And in this case it ought not to require much effort to append one's name to a protest against cruelty to poor, defenceless birds, and wanton destruction of animal life. I hope to see within the next day or two a still more emphatic expression of opinion than that already made in the columns of the "Gazette."

It seems somewhat remarkable to find in a hospital report that it is claimed that the year 1904 has been "a year of advance," in consequence of the "marked progres in numbers" (of patients treated) that has taken place. After this one may expect prison or lunatic asylum authorities making it a matter of congratulation that the number of inmates shows similar "marked progress."

For the inference to be drawn is certainly that, like crime, disease is on the increase in this country. The hospital to which I refer is that of the C.M.S. at Old Cairo, whose medical mission seems to be attended with the same amount of success that generally follows missionary work when directed towards alleviating human suffering.
As for the main purpose for which missionary societies are established, the following extract from the report tells its own tale :

"Tangible spiritual results are few indeed, and were those our only guarantee of success, and were it not for the knowledge that results are in higher hands, it would be truly hard, having put one's hand to the plough, not to look back."

Nor is the C.M.S. in Cairo alone in its lament over its non-success in proselytising. Major-General Sir Alexander Tulloch, in a letter to the London "Times," quotes the following statement made by a medical missionary working among the mountains in the north of India.
"I have been at work now for 15 years. I do not believe I have made one sincere convert, but I have operated successfully for stone on over 1,000 natives."

It is impossible to shut one's eyes to the fact that an immense amount of good is done by foreign missionaries, but it is equally impossible to doubt that it is done in a very different direction to that generally understood to be the one intended by "the kind-hearted old ladies who so liberally subscribe (I quote Major-General Tulloch) to the conversion of the poor benighted heathern who bow down to stocks and stone." Had it not been for the openings that presented themselves for medical and educational work –– opportunities of which the quick-witted Americans were not slow to avail themselves –– foreign missions would have been in a far more hopeless position to-day than they are.

But the old original tale is told, and the pretence made that the real good done is only a secondary consideration, and thus the money for the support of missions is obtained under what, to speak plainly, are nothing but
false pretences, and the old stock tales of "conversions" are as greedily swallowed now as they were when as a boy I attended the many missionary meetings to which my good mother took me.

But I used to do little sums in arithmetic, and sometimes was fairly staggered at the exceeding great cost of "conversions," and as my eyes became open to the misery and sin around me on every side, and the want of help at home, I somehow lost interest in foreign missions, feeling that the money they cost could be better spent in England, although it has been only recently that I have been able to estimate the cock-and-bull stories to which I listened in the days of my youth, at their true value.

Mr. Rudolph has rendered yeoman's service to the cause of humanity in the past, but he probably never helped the cause of truth and honesty more than by his letter in last Wednesday's paper. Nor did he err on the side of want of charity, for he could have made out a much stronger case than he did, and I should not wonder if there is a good deal of flatter in the dove cotes, not unmixed with anxiety as to what further relevations he may make as to so-called conversions of Jews.
"A Native of Upper Egypt" has also had something to say as to missions to Mohamedans, and altogether more than a little light has been thrown on mission work during the past few days.

A very valuable book entitled "The Principles of Heredity," by Dr. G. Archdall Reid, has lately been published, about which I hope to be able to write at some length when I have completed my study of it. Valuable as a medical treatise on a subject upon which hitherto no text books have appeared, the technical part of the work is small compared with the matter that the general reader can appreciate, and the concluding chapters, in which the subject is approached from the mental and religious point of view, are instructive in the highest degree.

The author makes frequent extracts from the writings of Professor James of Harvard University, whose recently published work, "Varieties of Religious Experience," is one that no student of the different phases of religious beliefs, emotion, and experience should omit to read. It is in the Ramleh Library, and perhaps is also obtainable at Cairo.

The volume consists of the Gifford lectures delivered at Edinburgh University in 1901-2, and it contains many very striking features, one of the most interesting of which is the discussion of the phenomenon of conversion. The views of so eminent a psychologist on such a matter are well worth studying, however disposed orthodox theologians may be to pick holes in them, and to dispute the professor's conclusions.
After an exhaustive analysis of religious experiences, which extends over nearly 500 pages, the professor asks, "Is the existence of so many religious types and sects and creeds regrettable?"

And to this question he answers emphatically "No," giving many cogent reasons for this conclusion, which I regret I have not sufficient space now to enumerate. The high spiritual discernment of the author is evidenced all throughout the book –– a very rare thing in purely scientific literature, –– which greatly adds to its value.

As I have not of late signed my full name to these nates, and, in this paper, have remarked on the necessity of signatures to personal expressions of opinion, I will append mine this week, although it is pretty generally understood that T.A. stands for
Thos. Atwood.

div.head: GREEK DEBT CONVERSION
div.p: The rumours which have been for some time in circulation pointing to a conversion of the foreign debt of Greece are taking more definite shape. The process, it is said, will be similar to that employed in connection with the Turkish debt. As with that affair, a French syndicate has the matter in hand, and two of its members have been despatched to Athens to impress upon the Greek Government the advantages of unification. Terms are not likely to be arranged for some little time at least to come, but no doubt they will represent an improvement upon the present position, though in return for this something will have to be sacrificed in the way of further developments, and, as we know, the revenues of the country have been on an improving scale for a considerable period. British holders of Greek obligations are numerous, and it is to be hoped that they will insist against the interference with the powers of the International Commission, which was appointed in 1897-8. The Guaranteed Loan would, of course, be excluded from the scheme.

div.head: THE SUEZ CANAL
RETURNS OF SHIPPING AND TONNAGE.
div.p: The returns of the navigation through the Suez Canal for the year 1904, as compared with those of the two previous years 1902 and 1903, show that the net tonnage for the pasy year increased by 1,494,547 tons as compared with that of 1903, and by 2,153,422 tons as compared with that of 1902. Notwithstanding the reduction of 50 centimes in the tonnage dues which took effect from the 1st January, 1903, the transit receipts during that year amounted to fr. 103,620,268, or only fr. 99,752 less than those of 1902, while those for last year amounted to fr. 115,818,479, and were higher than in any previous year since the opening of the Canal. The increase in the tonnage passing through the Suez Canal during 1904 is owing to heavy shipments of wheat from India to Europe, and to the large quantities of coal consigned to the East, which latter exceed by about 500,000 tons the shipments during the year 1903, and which were, no doubt, principally for the use of the belligerent fleets.

The number of vessels which passed through the Canal was 3,708 in 1902, 3,761 in 1903, and 4,237 in 1904, of which 2,165 in 1902, 2,278 in 1903, and 2,679 in 1904 carried the British flag. There has been an increase of 1,430,376 tons last year as compared with 1903 in the tonnnage of British vessels, which amounted to 6,772,911 tons in 1902, 7,403,553 tons in 1903, and 8,833,929 tons in 1904. During the same period, the tonnage of German vessels has increased from 1,707,322 tons in 1902 to 1,773,265 tons in 1903, and to 1,969,661 tons in 1904.

The percentage of British vessels and their net tonnage increased in 1904, being 63.2 and 65.9 respectively, as against 60.6 and 62.2 in 1903 and 58.4 and 60.2 in 1902. The percentage of German vessels and their net tonnage was 12.8 and 14.7 respectively, as compared with 13.1 and 14.9 in 1903, and 12.9 and 15.2 in 1902, while the percentage of net tonnage of the other maritime nations using the Canal in 1904 remained practically stationary as compared with the preceding year.

Of 3,289 merchant-vessels and vessels in ballast, of a net tonnage of 10,316,600 tons, passing through the Canal, 2,433 ships, of a net tonnage of 7,847,307 tons, were British, being fully 74 per cent. of the number and fully 76.06 per cent. of the tonnage ; 356, or 13.8 per cent., were German vessels, whose tonnage was 10.5 per cent. of the whole ; France, Holland, Norway, Austria-Hungary, and Italy combined furnishing a total of 10.5 per cent. of the tonnage carrying trade to the East through the Suez Canal.

In the ten years 1891-1900, the annual net tonnage ranged from 8,698,777 tons to 9,738,152 tons, and the transit receipts from fr. 83,422,101 to fr. 90,623,608 The average of the net tonnage was 8,588,947 tons ; while in 1904 the net tonnage amounted to 13,401,835 tons, and the transit receipts to fr. 115,818,479. The mean net tonnage per vessel, which in 1881 was only 1,517 tons, rose from 2,067 tons in 1891 to 2,926 tons in 1901, and amounted to 3,163 tons in 1904. During last year the Canal was used 63 times by steamers exceeding 150 metres (492 feet) in length or more than 18 metres (59 feet) in breadth, with a draught of over 7 metres 50 (24 feet 7 inches).

The mean duration of passage for all vessels navigating the Canal was 17 hours 48 minutes in 1903 as compared with 18 hours 8 minutes in 1904, while the percentage of vessels navigating by night amounted to 96.1 per cent. in 1903 as compared with 95.7 per cent. in 1904.

The percentage of vessels drawing less than 24 ft. 7 in. (7 m. 50 c.) was 83.3 in 1904 as against 84.9 in 1903, while that of vessels drawing more than 24 ft. 7 in. was 16.7 in 1904 as compared with 15.1 in 1903. Up to the end of the year 1901, the maximum draught allowed for vessels passing through the Canal was fixed at 25 feet 7 inches, and during 1904, 705 vessels, drawing more than 24 feet 7 inches, used the Canal, as compared with 566 in 1903 and 431 in 1902, representing a percentage of 11.6 in 1902, 15.1 in 1903, and 16.7 in 1904. Since the 1st January, 1902, the maximum draught allowed has been raised to 26 feet 3 inches (8 metres), and during last year 145 vessels, or 3.4 per cent., took advantage of this improvement. During 1904 377 vessels passed through the Canal for the first time, of which 92 belonged to shipping companies whose vessels regularly use the Canal.

The number of troops carried through the Canal during last year amounted to 81,431 as against 80,583 in 1903, being an increase of 848. There was an increase of 7,092 British, 190 Dutch, 137 Russian, 109 Portuguese, and 341 American, against a decrease of 4,222 French, 1,296 Italian, 1,202 Turkish, and 18 German troops as compared with 1903. The number of civilian passengers amounted to 90,708 in 1904 as against 89,272 in the preceding year, being an increase of 1,436, while the number of pilgrims, emigrants, and convicts was 38,706 in 1904, as compared with 25,362 in 1903, or an increase of 13,344.

In the year 1870,26,758 civil and military passengers were carried through the Canal ; in 1880 the number rose to 98,900, in 1890 to 161,352, in 1900 to 282,203, and in 1904 it amounted to 210,849, as against 195,232 in 1903.

div.head: THE GERMAN ARMY.
div.p: The text of the Bill passed recently, which alters the method of recruiting the German Army, has just been officially released. Henceforward every German who is medically fit will have to serve seven years in the active army, from the age of twenty to twenty-seven and a day. He will then pass into the first category of the Landwehr, in which he will remain five years, and will then be enrolled in the second category until the 21st March of the year in which he reaches the age of thirty-nine. During the seven years of their active service the cavalry and artillery will have to remain three years with the colours, and the infantry two years. The reservists of all arms will have to serve eight weeks, at two different periods, and there are also alterations in the service of the Landwehr. At the same time, the numbers of the army are to be gradually increased, so that in 1910 the army will include 505,039 men, 25,000 officers, 85,000 non-commissioned officers, and 10,000 volunteers for a year. These figures do not include the marines, the gendarmerie, and the soldiers serving in China. In this manner the German army in 1910 will be increased to 633 battalions of infantry, 510 squadrons of cavalry, and 574 field batteries, while all the other branches will be proportionally augmented. It is evident that the policy of the Kaiser does not tend towards peace, for this enormous increase takes place at a time when the Navy is also being brought up to first-class rank, while on land the Russian army has been hopelessly defeated, and the stationary population of France makes it harder every year to keep the army of the Republic up to its normal standard.

div.head: A DOG AND A TRAGEDY
div.p: The story of the dog who recently caused the discovery of a tragedy at Bridgend by barking outside the house in which it occurred recalls a sensational incident that took place in Grand Canary a few years ago (says the "Chronicle"). A young American was mudered for his money in one of the Spanish inns near the harbour, and his fox-terrier was carried off to a plantation in the hills by one of the accomplices. Two whole years the later the dog was brought back again to the town, and it immediately went to a certain hole in the road, tried to scratch a hole in it, and howled so piteously that it attracted the attention even of the Spanish policeman. This led to the discovery of its master's body and the final conviction of his murderer.

div.head: ATHENS WATER SYNDICATE.
div.p: It is announced that a powerful London syndicate has been formed, supported by some of the most influential residents in Athens and the Piraeus, to carry out a project for furnishin Athens with an improved water supply. Mr. Bailey-Denton, of the well-known firm of Messrs. Bailey-Denton, Lawford, and Symons, of Westminster, has left London with a staff to carry out the necessary preliminary work, which includes a survey from Athens to the proposed mode of supply –– a distance of about ninety miles. It is estimated that the outlay involved will amount to over a million sterling.

div.head: REVOLT AGAINST PARIS MODES.
div.p: The National Assembly of Dressmakers, meeting at Chicago last week, passed a resolution protesting against allegiance to Paris fashions. They declared (says the "Telegraph's" correspondent) that the American woman is built upon a different plan from the French, and should have a style distinctively her own. The dressmakers declared that the time is approaching when Europe will look to America for fashion, and not America to Europe.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: On a pu assister a une agreable surprise a la un de ce mois qui avait si mal commence et qui semblait devoir se clore par une liquidation des plus laborieuses. Contrairement a l'ordre normal, l'animation a reparu au moment de la liquidation et la cote est remontee sur presque toute la ligne. Cet effet, contraire a toutes les previsions, a ete determine par deux mobiles principaux : d'une part, la defaite navale russe qui permet d'envisager la paix comme prochaine et, de l'autre, les mesures de precaution prises par les speculateurs trop engages qui avaient eu l'occasion lors des deux dernieres liquidations de voir ce qu'il en coutait d'attendre au dernier moment pour alleger des positions intenables. Ces allegements ont beaucoup contribue a assainir la place, mais c'est au seul desastre russe qu'il faut attribuer la hausse a Londres et par contre-coup en Egypte, dont le marche depend surtout de Londres. Ajoutons a ce propos que les bourses de tous les pays attendent impatiemment la paix et cela est si vrai que la Bourse de Paris a ete elle-meme fort peu affectee par la nouvelle du desastre russe, dans l'espoir sans doute que ce desastre, de tous le plus irreparable, amenera enfin la paix.

Au debut de la periode que nous passons en revue, l'attention etait concentrate presque uniquement sur la Daira Sanieh et sur les actions Credit Foncier Egyptien. Aux termes de l'accord intervenu entre les deux societes tout l'actif et le passif de la Daira passerait au Credit Foncier moyennant un paiement par ce dernier de £.9.900.000 qu'il se procurerait par l'emission de £.6.600.000 d'obligations (Avec un interet probable de 3%) et de £.3.300.000 d'actions emises au cours de 825 francs. Ces deux emissions sont deja garanties par deux syndicate. Les actions nouvelles du Credit Foncier seront entierement reservees aux actionnaires actuels dans la proportion d'une action nouvelle pour deux anciennes et de 50 actions nouvelles pour une part de fondateur. Quant aux actions Daira, on dit qu'elles seront payees a raison de 30 a 30 ½ £. les actions ordinaires et 200 £. les actions Deferred. Les porteurs de Daira's attendaient a beaucoup mieux ou du moins escomptaient l'echange de leurs titres-contre des titres Credit Foncier. Les actions Credit Foncier elles-memes n'ont guere profite du nouvel etat de choses et, a moins qu'un mouvement a la hausse ne se dessine bientot, l'emission des actions nouvelles Foncier ne pourrar reussir.

De 29 1/8 au debut la Daira flechit graduellement a 28 11/16 ; on comprend qu'a ce prix c'est un placement avantageux, meme si la liquidation de fin octobre se fait seulement a £30. Par contre, la Fondateur Daira remonte de 178 £ a 185 acheteurs. Pour le Credit Foncier il se produit le meme mouvement en sens inverse : l'action flechit de 832 a 826 pendant que la Fondateur monte de 7500 fr. a 7900.

De 13 ½ au debut, l'Agricole flechit plus tard a 13 ¼ sous la pression des ventes fin du mois, mais elle ne tarde pas a reprendre a la nouvelle que l'emission d'actions au pair, au lieu d'etre retardee jusqu'en octobre, comme on le supposait, aura lieu tres prochainement. On cloture a 14 tres ferme et en bonne tendance. Le chiffre d'affaires a ete enorme.

Delaissee d'abord a 27 ½, la National Bank revient en faveur et atteint £28 l'action ancienne et £ 26 13/16 la nouvelle. Ce dernier prix est egalement celui de la National Bank ex-droit de souscription. Le prochain lancement de la Banque Nationale d'Abyssinie dans lequel la National Bank est fortement interesse, est pour beaucoup dans la hausse du cours.
La Land Bank a fluctue entre 9 et 9 1/8, pour cloturer a ce dernier prix. Les operations ont ete assez nombreuses.
De 13 la Delta Light reprend a 13 ¼, pour retomber bientot entre 13 1/16 et 13 1/8. Cette valeur, qui semble en ce moment peu recherchee, ne tarders pas a revenir en vogue.

En Banque d'Athenes on fluctue entre 121 et 124, pour finir a 123. Le mouvement d'affaires a ete considerable. La hausse provient en partie du prochain lancement d'un Credit Foncier Hellenique sous le patronage de la Banque d'Athenes.

Tres faible deja a 33/, la Salt & Soda a encore flechi jusqu'a 32/3 a la suite de ventes importantes, provenant des porteurs d'actions Huileries qui vendaient le resultat de leur faculte d'obtenir 11 actions Salt & Soda au cours de 32 shellings, plus 23 actions Salt & Soda contre une action Huileries. Ces ventes etant terminees, le marche a deja repris et le cours a regagne 35/6, pour finir acheteur a 35/.
Apres avoir debute a 1 15/16, l'Investment a flechi jusqu'a 1 19/32 sur les ventes forcees de certains petits speculateurs qui se sont trouves dans l'impossibilite de recevoir ou du

fait de certains autres qui escomptaient des prix beaucoup plus bas pour la liquidation de fin du mois. On cloture a 1 25/32 en bonne demande. La societe est en train de conclure plusieurs affaires qui promettent de beaux profits.

Le meme mouvement a eu lieu sur les Estates et pour les memes motifs. Le cours, apres avoir flechi de 31/32 a 13/16m est remonte a 31/32 acheteurs, avec des transactions se chiffrant par milliers de titres.
De forts paquest de Trust ont egalement change de mains a un cours variant de 1 ¼ a 1 5/16.
La Behera debute a 45 5/8, atteint 46 et retombe en cloture a 45. L'action de jouissance est demandee a 5 1/16.
En Delta Land les affaires ont ete restreintes. Le cours flechit de 2 9/16 a 2 7/16.
La Ramleh demeure stationnaire a 7 ¾.
Les Priviligiees Tramways ont donne lieu a d'importantes transactions entre 154 et 155 ½. On cloture a 149 ½ ex-coupon (6 fr. 50.)
Sur un rapport des plus satisfaisants et sur la nouvelle definitive d'un dividende de 9 %, l'Anglo-American Nile reprend eufiu de 5 9/16 a 5 11/16 acheteurs.
La Khedivial Mail monte de 4 1/16 a 4 ¼ pour finir a 4 1/8.
De 1 1/16 l'Oasis tombe a 15/16, mais reprend bientot a £1 acheteurs.
Les Brasseries demeureut sans changements appreciables, celles d'Alexandrie a 205 ex-coupon, et celle du Caire a 122.
Le chiffre d'affaires en Markets a ete assez important. Le cours debute a 22/6 et cloture a 22/3 acheteurs.
Les Eaux du Caire flechissent de 1150 a 1130 francs et l'Alexandria Water Co. de 16 a 15 7/8, avec affaires tres limitees.
L'Urbaine est ferme entre 4 5/16 et 4 3/8.

En resume le marche a l'air un peu plus sain et la tendance est bonne. Il semble bien, cependant, que l'heure soit peu propice aux emissions de nouvelles societes. Celles-ci feront bien, a notre avis, d'atteudre pour se lancer, le mois d'octobre, epoque a laquelle le courant est generalement a la hausse.
Le marche a ouvert ce matin avec beaucoup d'animation ; mais, vers la fin, la liquidation de fin du mois a pese un peu sur les cours et il se pourrait que la faiblesse persiste encore lunci.
La National Bank hausse de 28 a 28 1/16, la Banque d'Athenes de 123 a 123 ¾, la Salt & Soda de 35 a 35/6, l'Anglo American Nile de 5 11/16 a 5 ¾ et les Privilegiees Tramways de 149 ½ a 151.
Par contre l'Agricole flechit de 14 a 13 15/16, la Land Bank de 9 1/8 a 9 1/16, la Delta Land de 2 ½ a 2 7/16, l'Alexandria Water de 15 15/16 a 15 7/8.
Les Estates, apres avoir atteint a l'ouverture 1 1/16, ont flechi en cloture a £1 acheteurs.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE

Remarques
(De Midi à 1h. p.m.)

Cotons.— Le juillet a continue a se ressentir de l'offre persistante de quelques vendeurs et la cloture a fini par etre faible. On croit toujours cependant que d'un moment a l'autre nous pourrions bien avoir une surprise a la hausse.
Le novembre a montre beaucoup de fermete et sans le recul du juillet, nous n'aurions pas meme eu le 1/32 de reaction de la derniere heure.
